author: potuz
content: PBS is a protocol level version of MEV-boost. There is no fixed spec decided, but all proposals have some features in common: both validator (proposer) and builder are recognized parties within the protocol. A block is divided in two parts, a consensus part and an execution part, validators have to attest to both. If the builder does not submit his block the proposer gets paid anyway.

author: butta
content:
> builder are recognized parties within the protocol.

author: potuz
content: in PBS validators and builders are separate entities, there's no protocol spec for it and nothing has been set for questions like "what are slashable offenses by the builder" etc. My personal guess is that validators will be elligible for being builders, but there may be others that are not necessarily validators. In all proposals that I have seen, validators choose the builder via a bidding process and sign their blind block with the chosen bid. If such a proposal is approved, then nothing will prevent a validator from being his own builder at the time: just chose your own hash regardless of bids.

author: yokem55
content:
The analogy to an ISP isn't quite right. It might work for simple node operators who are just distributing block and transaction data already committed to the  chain.

What a court or regulator might analogize block builders/relays/proposers to is the visa network. On the visa network, if bank X is sanctioned, can their customers still transact with other folks with Bank Y that is non-sanctioned? Is visa compelled to block those transactions?

If yes, it is because the power to apply fine grained censorship already exists in visa's role. And the same fine grained censorship power exists for builders and relays as well. It literally is how they make money, by taking the highest bribe to take the transaction from party A instead of lower bidding party B. Party B's transaction is censored because they didn't pay a high enough bribe and their transaction would revert if sent to the chain.
